hints_html:
A matrix M is called

  • hermitian if \(M = \overline{M^T}\)

  • real symmetric if all entries of M are real and M = MT.

  • unitary if MM* = M*M = I, where \(M^* = \overline{M^T}\).

  • orthogonal if MMT = MTM = I.

For real matrices the conditions hermitian and real symmetric are equivalent. Further, for real matrices the conditions unitary and orthogonal are equivalent.

A square matrix is orthogonal if the columns (or rows) form an orthonormal basis.

question: 6 (a)
sols_html:
Since all matrices are real, hermitian, real symmetric and symmetric are equivalent, and so are unitary and orthogonal.

U and V are: hermitian ☐, real symmetric ☐, unitary ☒, orthogonal ☒

We easily see that U is symmetric but V is not. Hence, together, they are neither hermitian nor real symmetric. Since the columns of U and V are orthonormal, both matrices are unitary and orthogonal. This can be seen for U since

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ 1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ 1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} &= 1 \\ \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ 1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ -1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} &= 0 \\ \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ 1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} &= 0 \\ \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ -1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ -1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} &= 1 \\ \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ -1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} &= 0 \\ \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} &= 1\end{aligned}\]

The corresponding vector multiplications give the same result for V.

\(\Sigma\) is: hermitian ☒, real symmetric ☒, unitary ☐, orthogonal ☐

Since \(\Sigma\) is diagonal it is cleary symmetric. However, the first and the third column vectors don’t have length 1 and hence \(\Sigma\) is not unitary or orthogonal.

\(A^*A\) and \(AA^*\) are: hermitian ☒, real symmetric ☒, unitary ☐, orthogonal ☐

Following the rules of transposition of matrix products we quickly check that (A*A)* = A*((A*)*) = A*A and correspondingly (AA*)* = ((A*)*)A* = AA* so that \(A^*A\) and \(AA^*\) are indeed unitary and hence also real symmetric. Next, observe that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle A^*A = (U\Sigma V^*)^*(U\Sigma V^*) = V\Sigma^2 V^{-1}\end{aligned}\]

since, from the above, U and V are unitary. The equation above however describes a diagonalization of A*A, and hence the eigenvalues of A*A are found on the diagonal of \(\Sigma^2\), namely 4, 1, 1/4. However, all eigenvalues of a unitary matrix must have an absolute value of 1. Hence A*A is not unitary and not orthogonal. The equivalent argument also shows that AA* is not unitary and not orthogonal.

A is: hermitian ☐, real symmetric ☐, unitary ☐, orthogonal ☐

Since the largest singular value corresponds to the matrix norm of A it follows that \(\|A\| = 2\), while unitary and orthogonal matrices have norm 1. To check if A is symmetric we start by checking the entries a2,1 and a1,2 for equality.

\[\begin{aligned} A &= \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\ 1/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1/2 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt 3 & 1/\sqrt 3 & 1/\sqrt 3 \\ 0 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 \\ 2/\sqrt 6 & -1/\sqrt 6 & -1/\sqrt 6 \end{bmatrix} \\ &= \begin{bmatrix} 2/\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\ 2/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1/2 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt 3 & 1/\sqrt 3 & 1/\sqrt 3 \\ 0 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 \\ 2/\sqrt 6 & -1/\sqrt 6 & -1/\sqrt 6 \end{bmatrix} \\ &= \begin{bmatrix} * & \frac2{\sqrt 6}+\frac12 & * \\ \frac2{\sqrt 6} & * & * \\ {}* & * & * \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

We see that a2,1 \(\neq\) a1,2 and hence A is not hermitian or real symmetric.

sols_latex:
Since all matrices are real, \textbf{hermitian}, \textbf{real symmetric}
and \textbf{symmetric} are equivalent, and so are \textbf{unitary} and
\textbf{orthogonal}.

\subparagraph{\emph{U} and \emph{V} are: hermitian ☐, real symmetric ☐,
unitary ☒, orthogonal
☒}\label{u-and-v-are-hermitian-real-symmetric-unitary-orthogonal}

We easily see that \emph{U} is symmetric but \emph{V} is not. Hence,
together, they are neither hermitian nor real symmetric. Since the
columns of \emph{U} and \emph{V} are orthonormal, both matrices are
unitary and orthogonal. This can be seen for \emph{U} since

\begin{align*}
\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ 1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ 1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} &= 1 \\
\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ 1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ -1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} &= 0 \\
\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ 1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} &= 0 \\
\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ -1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ -1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} &= 1 \\
\begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt2 \\ -1/\sqrt2 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} &= 0 \\
\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} &= 1
\end{align*}

The corresponding vector multiplications give the same result for
\emph{V}.

\subparagraph{$\Sigma$ is: hermitian ☒, real symmetric ☒, unitary ☐,
orthogonal
☐}\label{sigma-is-hermitian-real-symmetric-unitary-orthogonal}

Since $\Sigma$ is diagonal it is cleary symmetric. However, the first
and the third column vectors don't have length 1 and hence $\Sigma$ is
not unitary or orthogonal.

\subparagraph{$A^*A$ and $AA^*$ are: hermitian ☒, real symmetric ☒,
unitary ☐, orthogonal
☐}\label{aa-and-aa-are-hermitian-real-symmetric-unitary-orthogonal}

Following the rules of transposition of matrix products we quickly check
that \emph{(A\textsuperscript{*}A)\textsuperscript{*} =
A\textsuperscript{*}((A\textsuperscript{*})\textsuperscript{*}) =
A\textsuperscript{*}A} and correspondingly
\emph{(AA\textsuperscript{*})\textsuperscript{*} =
((A\textsuperscript{*})\textsuperscript{*})A\textsuperscript{*} =
AA\textsuperscript{*}} so that $A^*A$ and $AA^*$ are indeed unitary and
hence also real symmetric. Next, observe that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
A^*A = (U\Sigma V^*)^*(U\Sigma V^*) = V\Sigma^2 V^{-1}
\end{align*}

since, from the above, \emph{U} and \emph{V} are unitary. The equation
above however describes a diagonalization of
\emph{A\textsuperscript{*}A}, and hence the eigenvalues of
\emph{A\textsuperscript{*}A} are found on the diagonal of $\Sigma^2$,
namely 4, 1, 1/4. However, all eigenvalues of a unitary matrix must have
an absolute value of 1. Hence \emph{A\textsuperscript{*}A} is not
unitary and not orthogonal. The equivalent argument also shows that
\emph{AA\textsuperscript{*}} is not unitary and not orthogonal.

\subparagraph{\emph{A} is: hermitian ☐, real symmetric ☐, unitary ☐,
orthogonal ☐}\label{a-is-hermitian-real-symmetric-unitary-orthogonal}

Since the largest singular value corresponds to the matrix norm of
\emph{A} it follows that $\|A\| = 2$, while unitary and orthogonal
matrices have norm 1. To check if \emph{A} is symmetric we start by
checking the entries \emph{a\textsubscript{2,1}} and
\emph{a\textsubscript{1,2}} for equality.

\begin{align*}
A &= \begin{bmatrix}
1/\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\
1/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}
2 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1/2
\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}
1/\sqrt 3 & 1/\sqrt 3 & 1/\sqrt 3 \\
0 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 \\
2/\sqrt 6 & -1/\sqrt 6 & -1/\sqrt 6
\end{bmatrix} \\
&= \begin{bmatrix}
2/\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\
2/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1/2
\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}
1/\sqrt 3 & 1/\sqrt 3 & 1/\sqrt 3 \\
0 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 \\
2/\sqrt 6 & -1/\sqrt 6 & -1/\sqrt 6
\end{bmatrix} \\
&= \begin{bmatrix}
* & \frac2{\sqrt 6}+\frac12 & * \\
\frac2{\sqrt 6} & * & * \\
{}* & * & *
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align*}

We see that \emph{a\textsubscript{2,1} $\neq$ a\textsubscript{1,2}} and
hence \emph{A} is not hermitian or real symmetric.
